explanation: You must inspect any code that can execute as part of digest_update (including called functions and macros) because MISRA’s for-loop rule treats the behaviour of any functions called within the loop body as part of the loop body. Although digest_update itself contains no for loops, the three digest-update functions it calls (MHD_MD5_update, MHD_SHA256_update, MHD_SHA512_256_update) — and the low-level transform routines they call (md5_transform, sha256_transform, sha512_256_transform) — may contain for statements. Therefore provide their implementations so the analyser can find and check any for loops and verify the three MISRA clauses (loop counter usage, side effects, single counter not modified in body, etc.). Also include the mhd_assert macro definition because macro expansions could introduce for statements or affect control flow. Finally include the conditional compilation symbols (MHD_MD5_SUPPORT, MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT, MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT) so the analyser knows which update functions are actually present in the built configuration.
